{"step_by_step_thinking": "Ectoderm is one of the three primary germ layers in the developing embryo, and it gives rise to various structures including the epidermis, hair, nails, and enamel of teeth. To determine which structure is not of ectodermal origin, we need to identify which one does not arise from the ectoderm. 

A. Hunter-schreger bands are alternating light and dark bands seen in the enamel of teeth. They are formed by variations in the arrangement of enamel rods and are of ectodermal origin. 

B. Enamel spindles are small, hypomineralized areas that extend from the dentin into the enamel. They are formed during tooth development and are also of ectodermal origin. 

C. Enamel tufts are hypomineralized areas that extend from the dentin into the enamel. They are formed during tooth development and are also of ectodermal origin. 

D. Enamel lamellae are thin, partially mineralized cracks or defects in the enamel. They are formed during tooth development and are also of ectodermal origin.
